content.body: is there a way to get a native function in ECMAScript that do the following thing: `(f) => f()`? `this` and `arguments` are not important in my use case
content.formatted_body: is there a way to get a native function in ECMAScript that do the following thing: (f) => f()? this and arguments are not important in my use case

content.body: What's the reason for doing that rather than just writing `f=>f()`? This way is shorter, clearer, and safer since it's 100% syntax.
content.formatted_body: What's the reason for doing that rather than just writing f=>f()? This way is shorter, clearer, and safer since it's 100% syntax.

content.body:
> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> What's the reason for doing that rather than just writing `f=>f()`? This way is shorter, clearer, and safer since it's 100% syntax.

To make sure the debugger won't step in anything
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
What's the reason for doing that rather than just writing f=>f()? This way is shorter, clearer, and safer since it's 100% syntax.
To make sure the debugger won't step in anything

content.body: It will bring better debug experience
Nowadays I write proxies in this way
need a directive which says "debuggers should not stop in this function"
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: need a directive which says "debuggers should not stop in this function"

content.body: Like C#'s `[DebuggerStepThrough]` attribute. Maybe someday a `@debugger.StepThrough` meta decorator?
